div.p:
"
Deerely beloved
in the last Ser
mon you lear
ned what the
word of God is,
from whence it
came, by whom
it was chiefelie
revealed, what
proceedings it had, & of what dignitie
& certaintie it is. Nowe am I come a
gain, and by Gods favor and the help
of your prayers, I will declare unto
you (beloved) to whome and to what
ende the word of God is revealed: in
what maner it is to be hearde, & what
the force thereof is or the effect.

Our God is the God of al men and
nations, who according to the saieng
of the Apostle, would have all men to
"
be saved, & to come to the knowledge
of the truth : and therefore hath he for
the benefite, life and salvation of all
men, revealed his word, that so in deed
there might bee a rule and certaine
way, to lead men by the path of justice
into life everlasting.

God verily in the
old time did shew himelfe to the Is
raelites, his holie and peculiar people,
more familiarly than to other nati
ons, as the Prophet saith: To Jaacob
hath he declared his statutes, and his
judgements to Israell: he hath not
dealt so with any nation, neyther
hath he shewed them his judgments:
and yet he hath not altogither been
carelesse of the Gentiles. For as to
the Ninivites he sent Jonas, so Esai
as, Jeremias, Daniell, and the other
Prophetes bestowed much labour in
"
teaching and admonishing the Gen
tiles. And those most ancient fathers.
Noe, Abraham, and the rest, did not
onelie instruct the Jewish people
which descended of them, but taught
their other sonnes also, the judge
mentes of God. Our Lorde Jesus
Christ verilie laieng open the whole
world before his disciples, said: Teach
all nations: Preach the Gospell to
all creatures.

And when as saint
Peter did not yet fully understande,
that the Gentiles also did appertaine
to the fellowshippe of the Church of
Christ, and that to the Gentiles also
did belong the preaching of the glad
tydinges of salvation, purchased by
Christ for the faithfull, the Lorde doth
instrnct him by a heavenly vision, by
speaking to him out of heaven, and by
the message which came from Corne
lius, as you knowe (doerely beloved)
by the history of the Actes of the Apo
stles. Let us therefore thinke (my bre
thren) that the worde of God and the
holie Scriptures, are revealed to all
men, to all ages, kindes, degrees, and
states throughout the worlde. For
the Apostle Paul also confirming the
same, saieth: whatsoever things are
written, are written for our learning,
that through patience, and com
fort of the Scriptures, wee may have
hope.

Let none of us therefore heereafter
say, what need I to care what is writ
ten to the Jewes in the olde Testa
ment, or what the apostles have writ
ten to the Bomanes, to the Corinthi
ans, and to other nations : I am a
Christian. The Prophets to the men
of their time, and the apostles to those
that lived in the same age with them
did both preach and write. For if wee
thinke uprightlie of the matter, wee
shall see that the Scriptures of the
"
olde and newe Testamentes, ought
therfore to be received of us, even bi
cause wee are Christians. For Christ
our savior and master, did referre
us to the written bookes of Moses and
the Prophetes.

Saint Paule the very
elect instrument of Christ, doth ap
ply to us the Sacraments and exam
ples of the old Fathers, that is to saie,
Circumeision in Baptisme, Coloss2.
and the Paschall lambe in the supper
or sacrament 1. Cor. 5.

In the tenth
Chapter of the same Epistle he appli
eth sundry examples of the fathers to
us. And in the fourth to the Romanes
where hee reasoneth of faith, which
justifieth without the help of works,
and the lawe, hee bringeth in the ex
ample of Abraham. And therewithall
addeth, Neverthelesse it is not writ
ten for Abraham alone, that faith
was reckoned unto him for righte
ousnesse, but also for us to whom lit
shall be reckoned if we beleeve, &c.

By that meanes say some, we shall
againe bee wrapped in the lawe, wee
shall be iuforced to be circumcised, to
sacrifice flesh and blood of beastes, to
admit againe the priesthood of Aaron,
togither with the temple, and the o
ther ceremonies.
There shall againe be allowed the
bill of divorcement, or putting awaie
of a mans wife, togither with suffe
raunce to marrie manie wives. To
these I answere, that in the old Testa
ment we must consider, that some
things ther are, which are for ever to
be observed, and some thinges which
are ceremoniall and suffered onely til
time of amendment. That time of a
mendment is the time of Christ, who
fulsilled the lawe, and tooke away the
curse of the lawe.
The same Christ chaunged Cir
cumcision into Baptisme. Hee with
"
his owne onelie sacrifice made an end
of all sacrifices, so that now in steade
of all sacrifices, there is left to us
that onelie sacrifice of Christ, where
in also we learne to offer our own ve
rie bodies and praiers togither with
good deedes, as spirituall sacrifices un
to God: Christ changed the priesthood
of Aaron for his owne, and the priest
hood of all Christians.

The temple of
God are wee in whom God by his spi
rite doth dwell. All ceremomes did
Christ make voide, who also in the
nineteenth of Matthew did abrogate
the bill of divorcement, togither with
the marriage of manie wives. But
although these ceremones, and some
externall actions were abrogated and
cleane taken away by Christ, that we
shuld not be bound unto themryet not,
withstanding, the Scripture which
was published touching them, was
not taken awaie or else made voide
by Christ. For there must for ever bee
in the church of Christ a certaine te
stimoniall, whereby we may learne
what manner of worshippings and fi
gures of Christ they of the olde time
had. Those worshippings and figures
of Christ must we at this date inter
pret to the church specially, and out of
them we must no lesse than out of the
writings of the newe Testament
preach Christ, forgivenes of sins, and
repentance. So then to all Christi
ans are the writings of the olde Te
stament given by God: in like maner
as the Apostles writ to all Churches
those things which bore the name or
title of some particular congrega
tions.

And to this end is the word of God
revealed to men, that it may teach
them what, and what maner one God
is towards men, that he woulde have
them to be saved, and that by faith in
"
Christ: what Christ is, and by what
meanes salvation commeth: what be
cometh the true worshippers of God,
what they ought to flie, and what to
ensue. Neither is it susficient to know
the wil of God, unlesse we do the same
and be saved. And for that cause saide
Moses, Heare lsrael the statutes and
judgements which I teach you, that
ye may doe them and live.

And the
Lorde in the Gospell confirming the
same, crieth: Blessed are they which
heare the word of God and keepe it.
And heere is to bee praised the ex
ceeding great goodnesse of God, which
would have nothing hid from us, which
maketh any whit to live rightly, well
and holily. The wise and learned of
this world doe for the most part heare
envie or grudge, that other shoulde
attaine unto the true wisedome. But
our Lord doth gently, and of his owne
accorde offer to us, the whole know
ledge of heavenlie things, and is desi
rous that we go forward therein, yea,
and that more is, he doth further our
labour, and bring it to an ende. For
whosoever hath, saith the Lord him
selfe in the Gospell, to him shall bee
given, that he may have the more a
bundance.

And everie one that as
keth receiveth, and he ghat seeketh
findeth, and to him that knocketh it
shal be opened. Wherupon S. James
the Apostle saith: If anie of you lacke
wisdom, let him aske of God, which
giveth to all men liberally, that is,
willingly not with grudging, nei
ther casteth anie man in the reeth, e
it shall be given him.

There, by the
way we see our dutie, which is in rea
ding and hearing the word of God, to
pray earnestly ad zealously, that wee
may come to that ende, for the which
the worde of God was given and re
vealed unto us. But as touching that
"
matter, wee will say somewhat more,
when we come to declare in what ma
ner of forte, the worde of God ought to
be heard.

Nowe, because I have sayde, that
the worde of God is revealed, to the
intente that it may fully instructe us
in the wayes of God and our salvati
on, I will in fewe words declare un
to you (dearely beloved) that in the
worde of God delivered to us by the
Prophets, and Apostles, is abundant
ly contayned the whole effect of god
lynesse, and what things soever are
is full and in al pointes perfect, to
availeable to the leading of our lives
rightly, well, and holily. For verily,
which nothing ought eyther to be
added, or else to be taken awaie.

But
it must needes be, that that doctrine
such a doctrine is the doetrine taught
in the worde of God, as witnesseth
Moses Deutr. 4. 6 12. And Salomon
Proverb. 30. what is he therefore that
doth not confesse that al pointes of
true pietie, are taught us in the sacred
Scriptures. Furthermore, no man can
denie that to be a most absolute do
ctrin, by which a ma is so fully made
perfect, that in this world he may be
taken for a just man, and in the world
to come, be called for ever to the co
panie of God.

But he that beleeveth
the word of God uttered to the world
by the Prophetes and Apostles, and
liveth thereafter, is called a just man,
and heire of life everlasting. That
doctine therefore is an absolute do
ctrine. For Paul also declaring more
largely & fully the same matter, saith:
All Scripture given by inspiration of
God, is profitable to doctrine to re
prove, to correction, to instruction
which is in righteousnesse, that the man
of God may be perfect, instructed to
all good workes.

"
Ye have (brethren) an evident testi
monie of the fulnesse of the worde of
God. He have a doctrin absolutely per
fect in al points. Ye have a most per
fect effect of the word of God, because
by this doctrine the man of God, that
is, the godly ond devout worshipper of
God, is perfect being instructed, not to
a cereaine few good works, but unto al
and every good worke. Wherin the re
fore canst thou finde anye want: I do
not thinke that any one is such a sot, as
to interprete these wordes of Paul, to
be spoken onely touching the olde Te
stamenteseeing it is more manifest tha
the Gospell, and was a Minister of the
ye day light, that Paule applied them
to his scholer Timothy, who preached
newe Testament. If so be then, that
the doctrine of the olde Testament be
of it selfe ful, by how much more shall
it be the fuller if the Volume of the
new Testament be added thereuntos

I am not so ignorant, but that I know
that the Lorde Jesus both did & spake
many things which were not written
by the Apostles. But it followeth not
therefore that the doctrin of the word
of God, taught by the Apostles, is not
absolutely perfect. For John the Apo
stle and Evangelist dooth freely con
fesse, that the Lorde did many other
thinges also, which were not written
in his booke: But immediatly hee ad
deth this and saith: But these are writ
ten, that ye might beleeve, that lesus
is Christ the sonne of God, and that in
oeleeving ye might have life through
his name. He affirmeth by this doc
trine, which hee conteined in writing,
that faith is fully taught, and that
through faith there is granted by God
everlasting life,
But the ende of absolute doctrine
is to be happie and perfectly blessed.
Since the, that that cometh to man by
"
the written doctrine of the Gospel, un
doubtedly that doctrine of the Gospell,
is most absolutely perfect.

I knowe, that the Lorde in the Gos
pell said, I have manie thinges to tell
you: but at this time you can not
beare them: But there withal I know
too, that he immediatly added this say
ing, But when the spirite of trueth
shall come he shall leade you into all
truth. I knowe furthemmore, that the
spirite of truth did come uppon his dis
ciples, and therefore I beleeve, that
they according to the true promise of
Christ were led into all truth, so that
it is most alluredly certaine, that no
thing was wanting in them.

But some there are, which when
they cannot denye this, do turne them
selves and say, that ye Apostles in deed
knewe all things, but yet taught them
not but by word of mouth onely, not
setting downe in writinge all those
thinges, which doe appertaine to true
godlinesse. As though it were likely
that Christ his most faithfull Apostles,
would upo spite, have kept backe any
thing from their posteritie. As though
in deede, he had lyed which said, These
thinges are written, that in beleeving
ye might have life everlasting. John
therfore did let passe nothing which be
longeth to our full instructing in the
faith. Luke did omit nothing. Neither
did the rest of the Apostles & disciples
of our Lorde Jesus Christ suffer any
thing to over: slip them. Paul also
wrote fourteene sundrie Epistles: but
yet the most of them conteined one
and the selfe same matter

>
Whereby we may very well coniec
ture, that in them is wholly compre
hended the absolute doctrine of godly
nesse. For he would not have repea
ted one and the selfe same thing so of
ten, to so many sundrye men, if there
"
had yet bene any thing else necessarie,
more fullie to be taught for the obtei
ning of salvation. Those things un
doubtedly would hee have taught, and
not have rehearsed one and the same
thing so many times. Verily in the
third chapter of his epistle to the E
phesians he doth affirme, that in the
two first Chapters of the same his e
pistle, hee did declare his knowledge in
the Gospell of Christ.
God (sayth he) by revelation she
wed the mysterie unto me as I wrote
before in sewe wordes, whereby when
ye read ye may understand my know
ledge in the mysterie of Christ.

And
this spake he touching that one and
onely Epistle, yea, & that too touching
the two first Chapters of that one E
pistle. Thereunto when the most
large and lightsome Letters or Epi
stles of saint Paul himelfe, and al
so of the other Apostles are added, who
I pray you unlesse hee bee altogether
without sense, wil once thinke that the
apostles have lefte in writing to us
their posterity, a doctrine not absolute
ly perfect.
As for those which do earnestly af
firme, that al points of godlines were
taught by the Apostles to the posterity
by word of mouth & not by writing
their purpose is to set to sale their
own, that is, mens ordinances in steed
of the word of God.

But against this poyson (my bre
thren) take this unto you for a medi
cine to expell it. Conferre the thinges
which these fellowes set to sale, un
der the colour of the Apostles Traditi
ons, taught by worde of mouth, and
not by writing, with the manifest
writinges of the Apostles, and if in a
nye place you shall perceyve those tra
ditions, to disagree with the Scrip
tures, the gather by & by, that it is the
"
forged invention of men, and not the
Apostles tradition.

For they, which
had one and the same Spirite of truth,
lefte not unto us one thing in writing,
and taught an other thing by worde of
mouth.

Furthermore, wee must diligently
search, whether those traditions do set
forwarde the glory of God, rather than
of men, or the safetie of the faithtull,
rather than the private aduauntage
of the Priestes.

And wee must take
heede of mennes Traditions, especial
ly since the Lorde sayth, In vaine doe
they worship me, teaching doctrines
the preceptes of men:

So that nowe,
the surest way is to cleave to the word
of the Lorde lefte to us in the Scrip
tures, which teacheth aboundantlye
all thinges that belong to true godly,
nesse.

It remaineth now for me to tell, in
what manner of fort this perfect doct
ctrine of godlines & salvatio, I meane,
the very word of god ought to be heard
of the faithtull, to the intent it may be
heard with some fruite to profit them
aboundantly. I will in few words co
teine it. Let the word of God be heard
with great reverece, which of right is
due to God himselfe and godly things.
Let it be heard very attentively: with
continuall prayers betweene and ear
nest requests. Let it be heard soderly to
our profit, that by it wee may become
the better, that God by us may be glo
rified, and not that we goe evriously a
bout to search out the hidden counsells
of God, or desire to be counted skilfull
and expert in many matters.
Let true faith, the glorie of God,
and our salvatio be appointed as the
measure and certayne ende of out
hearing and reading.

For In Exo
dus Moses the holy seruaunt of God
"
is commaunded to sanctifie the peo
ple, and make them in a readinesse to
heare the sacred Sermon which God,
himselfe did minde to make the next
day after. Moses therefore commeth
and demaundeth of the whole people
due obedience to be shewed, as well
to God, as to his Ministers. Then com
mandeth he them to wash their gar
ments, to absteine from their wives.
After that hee appointeth certaine li
mites, beyond which it was not law
full upon paine of death for them to
passe.
By this we plainely learne, that the
Lord doth require such to be his Disci
ples to heare him, as do specially shew
obedience and reverence to him in all
things,

For he being God speaketh to
us men, all we men owe unto God ho
nour and feare.
A man, unlesse hee become lowly,
humble, and obediet to God, is altoge
ther godlesse. Then is it required at the
handes of those which are meete hea
rers of the worde of God, that they lay
apart worldly affaires, which are sig
nified by the garments: to tread under
foote all filthinesse and uncleannesse of
soule and bodie: to refraive for a season
even from those pleasures which are
lawfull unto us.

The holye Ghoste dooth love the
mindes that are purely cleansed which
yet notwithstanding are not cleansed
but by the Spirite of God. Neede
full it is, to have a sincere beleefe in
God, and a readie good will and desire
to live according to that which is com
maunded in the word of God, Moreo
ver we must be wise to sobriety. Over
curious questions must bee set aside,
Let things profitable to salvation on
ly be learned.

Last of al let especiall heed be taken
"
in hearing and learning. For saith Sa
lomon, If thou wilt secke after wise
dome as after gold, thou shalt obteine
it. Againe he saith: The searcher out of
Gods majestie shall be overwhelmed
by his wonderfull glorie. And againe
he saith: Seeke not things too high for
thee, neither goe about to search out
things above thy strength: but what
God hath comanded thee, that thinke
thou alwayes on: and bee not over
evrious to knowe his infinite workes,
for it is not expedient for thee to see
his hidden secrets with thine eyes.
Whereupon the Apostle Paul saith,
Let no man thinke arrogantly of him
selfe, but so thinke that hee may bee
modest and sober, according as God
to everie one hath given the measure
of faith. And heereto belongeth that
which the same Apostle saith, Know
ledge puffeth up, and charitie dooth
edifie.

But chiefly we must beware of those
plagves, which choake the seede of the
word of God, and quenche it without
any fruite at all in the heartes of the
hearers. Those plagves and diseases
hathye Lord rehearsed or reckoned by
in the Parable of the Sower. For first
of all, wanton and vaine cogitations,
which alwaies lie wide open to the in
spirations of satan, & talk of naughtie
men, are plagves to the word of God.
Also voluptuous and daintie lovers of
this world, who cannot abide to suffer
any affliction for Christ and his Gos
pel, doo without any fruite at al heare
Gods worde, although they seeme to
give eare unto it very ioyfully.

Furthermore, the care of this world,
and the deceipt of riches, are moste
pestilent diseases in the hearers of the
word of God. For they doo not onely
hinder the seede that it cannot bring
foorth the fruit in their hearts, but also
"
they doo stirre up and egge men for
warde to gaine: say the worde of God,
and to afflict the earnest desires of
Gods worde. Heere therefore we must
take heede diligently, least being in
fected with these diseases, we become
vaine and unthankefull hearers of the
word of God.

Wee muste praye continuallye,
that the bountifull and liherall Lord
will vouchsafe to bestowe on us his
spirit, that by it the seede of Gods word
may be quickened in our heartes, and
that we as holy and right hearers of
his worde may beare fruite aboun
dantly to the glory of God, and the e
verlasting salvation of oure owne
soules.

For what will it avayle to heare
the word of God without faith, and
without the holy Spirite of God to
worke or stir inwardly in our hearts:
The Apostle Paul saith, Hee which
watereth is nothing, nor hee which
planteth, but it is God which giveth
increase. We have neede therefore of
Gods watering, that the word of God
may growe to a perfect age, may re
ceive increase, yea, and may come also
to the bringing foorth of ripe fruite
within our mindes.

The same Apo
stle Paule sayth, To us also is the
worde of God declared, even as unto
our fathers. But it avayled them no
thing to heare the worde, because
it was not joyned with Faythe in
them that heard it . For they dyed
in the desart. And immediatly after
hee sayth: Let us therefore doe our
best to enter into that rest, so that no
man die in the same erample of un
beleefe. If therefore that the worde
of God doo sound in our eares, and
therewithall the Spirite of God doo
shewe foorth his polver in our hearts,
and that we in faith doo truely receive
"
the worde of God, then hath the word
of God a mightie force and wonderful
effect in us. For it driveth away the
mistie darkenesse of exrors, it openeth
our eies, it converteth and enlighte
neth our mindes, and instructeth us
most fully and absolutely in truth and
godlinesse.

For the Prophet David in
his Psalmes beareth witnesse, & saith:
The lawe of the Lorde is perfeet con
verting the foule, the testimonie of
God is true and giveth wisedome un
to the simple: The commaundement
of the Lord is pure, and giveth light
into the eies. Furthermore the worde
of God doth feede, strenthen, confirme
and comfort our soules, it doth rege
nerate, cleanse, make ioifull, and joyne
us to God, yea and obtaineth al things
for us at Gods handes, setting us in a
most happie state, in so much that no
goods or treasure of the whole worlde
are to be compared with the worde of
God. And thus much doe we attribute
to the worde of God, not without the
testimonie of Gods worde. For, the
Lord by ye Prophet Amos doth threa
ten hunger & thirst, not to eate breade
and to drinke water, but to heare the
worde of God. For in the old and new
testamentes it is saide, that man doeth
not live by breade onelie, but by every
worde that proceedeth out of the
mouth of God.

And the Apostle Paul
saith, that all thinges in the Scriptures
are written for our learning, that by
patience and comfort of the scriptures
we might have hope. Also Peter saith
ye are borne anewe, not of corruptible
seede, but of incorruptible, by the
word of God which liveth and lasteth
for ever. And this is the worde which
by the gospell was preached unto you,
The Lorde also in the gospell beareth
witnesse to the same, and saith: Nowe
are yee cleane by the worde which I
"
have spoken unto you. Againe in the
gospell, hee cryeth, saying: lf anie man
loveth me, hee will keepe my saying,
and my father will love him, and wee
will come into him and make our
dwelling place in him. Jeremie saith
also, Thy worde became my comfort.
And the Prophet David saith, The
statutes of the Lord are right, and re
ioice the heart. Whereunto adde that
saying of the Lordes in the gospell, If
yee remaine in me, and my wordes re
maine in you, aske what yee will, and
it shall be done for you. In an other
place also the Prophet crieth, saying:
If yee be willing and will hearken, yee
shall cate the good of the land, but if
yee will not heare my worde, the sword
shall devoure you.

Moreover Moses
doth very often and largelie reckon by
the good thinges that shall happen to
them which obey the worde of God,
Leviticus 26. Deutero. 28. Where
fore David durst boldely preferre the
worde of God before all the pleasures
and treasures of this world. The feare
of the Lorde is cleane and endureth
for ever, the judgementes of the Lorde
are true and righteous altogethers
more to be desired are they than gold,
yea, than much fine gold : sweeter al
so than honie, and the dropping honie
combes. For by them thy seruaunt is
plainely tanght, and in keeping of
them there is a great advantage. There
fore is the lawe of thy mouth more
precious unto mee, than thousandes of
silver and golde. wnlesse my deligh
had beene in thy lawe, I had perished
in my miserie.

To this nowe doth ap
pertaine that parable in the gospell of
him which bought the precious pearle:
and of him also which solde all that hee
had, and bought the grounde wherein
hee knewe that treasure was hidde.
For, that precious pearle, and that
treasure are the gospell or worde of
God: which for the excellencie of it is,
in the Scriptures called a light, a fire, a
sword, a maule which breaketh stones,
a buckler, and by manie other names
like uuto these.

Dearely beloved, this houre yee
have heard our bountifull Lorde and
God, who woulde have all men saved
and to come to the knowledge of the
truth, howe he hath revealed his word
to al men throughout ye whole worlde,
to the intent, that all men in al places,
of what kinde, age, or degree soever
they be may knowe the truth, and bee
instructed in the true salvation, and
may learne a perfect way howe to live
rightly, well, and holily, so that the ma
of God may be perfect, instructed to al
good workes. For the Lorde in the
worde of trueth hath delivered to his
Church all that is requisite to true
godlinesse and salvation. Whatsoever
things are necessarie to bee knowne,
touthing God, the works, judgemets,
will and commaundementes of God,
touthing Christ, our faith in Christ,
and the duties of an holie life, all those
things I saye, are fully taught in the
worde of God. Neither needeth the
Church to crave of anie other, or else
with mens supplies to patch up that
which seemeth to bee wanting in the
worde of the Lorde. For the Lorde did
not onely, by the lively expressed voice
"
of the Apostles, teach our fathers the
whole summe of godlinesse and salva
tion, but did provide also, that it by the
meanes of the same Apostles, shoulde
be set down in writing. And that doth
manifestly appeare, that it was done
for the posterities sake, that is, for us,
and our successours, to the intent that
none of us nor ours should be seduced,
nor that false traditios should be popt
into anie of our mouthes in steede of
the trueth. Te must all therefore be
ware, we must all watch and sticke
fast unto the worde of God, which is
left to us in the scriptures by the Pro
phetes and Apostles. Finally, let our
care be wholie bent, with faith & pro
fite to heare whatsoever the Lorde de
clareth unto us:

Let us cast out and
treade under foote whatsoever by our
flesh, the worlde or the devill, is obiec
ted to be a let to godlinesse. Te know
what the deseases & plagves of ye seede
of Gods worde sowed in the hearts of
tho faithfull are. We know how great
the polver of Gods worde is in them
which heare it devoutly. Let us there
fore beseech our Lorde God to powre
into our mindes his holie spirite, by
whose vertue the seede of Gods worde
may be quickened in our hearts, to the
bringing foorth of much fruite, to the
salvation of our soules, and the glorie
of God our father. To whom be glorie
for ever.
